question_text: A 24-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department during the summer with fever, runny nose, cough, watery red eyes, and a diffuse macular rash. He recently emigrated from Yemen and has not received any vaccinations. His last sexual encounter was 6 months ago.On physical examination, temperature is 39.0 °C (102.2 °F), blood pressure is 137/84 mm Hg, pulse rate is 124/min, and respiration rate is 18/min. Oxygen saturation is 98% breathing ambient air. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival erythema, small white spots inside the cheeks, and a diffuse macular rash are noted.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is measles (Option C). Measles has re-emerged in the United States because of low vaccination rates and reintroduction of the virus from endemic countries. Measles is a highly contagious viral infection that presents with high fever, rhinorrhea, cough, Koplik spots (white spots insides the cheeks), conjunctivitis, and a diffuse macular rash. Complications include otitis media, pneumonia, encephalitis, subacute sclerosing panencephalitis, and death. Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of viral RNA in respiratory and urine samples and measles-specific IgM in serum confirm the diagnosis. Both tests are highly specific, but PCR has a sensitivity of nearly 100%; the rapid antigen tests have a sensitivity between 59% and 93%. Suspected cases should be reported to the local health department within 24 hours. Treatment of measles is supportive, and patients should be placed in a room with airborne precautions. This patient is not immunized against measles and is from a country where recent measles outbreaks are occurring. His clinical presentation, including conjunctivitis, cough, and Koplik spots, are highly suspicious for this re-emerging viral infection.Acute HIV infection (Option A) can present with fever and a rash but typically does not include runny nose, watery eyes, cough, and white spots inside the mouth. Additionally, his last sexual encounter was 6 months ago, making acute infection unlikely.Infectious mononucleosis is caused by viral infections, most commonly Epstein-Barr virus (Option B), and typically presents with fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and fatigue. Some patients may have palatal petechiae, splenomegaly, and occasionally a maculopapular rash. This patient does not have pharyngitis and has characteristic Koplik spots on examination; mononucleosis is unlikely.Mumps virus (Option D) is another re-emerging vaccine-preventable viral infection that can cause parotitis associated with low-grade fever, headache, and malaise. Complications include orchitis, meningitis, pancreatitis, encephalitis, and hearing loss. Real-time PCR of a buccal swab confirms the diagnosis; mumps-specific IgM can also be used. Mumps typically does not present with high fever, rash, cough, or rhinorrhea; this patient also lacks parotitis. Mumps is unlikely in this patient.Scarlet fever (Option E) is caused by infection with group A Streptococcus. Symptoms include fever and sore throat. Characteristic examination findings include a white coating on the tongue and a red and bumpy “strawberry” tongue. The rash seen with scarlet fever is blanching and papular with a sandpaper-like texture. This patient's presentation is not consistent with scarlet fever.
key_points: Measles presents with high fever, rhinorrhea, cough, Koplik spots (white spots inside the cheeks), conjunctivitis, and a diffuse macular rash.
references: Hübschen JM, Gouandjika-Vasilache I, Dina J. Measles. Lancet. 2022;399:678-690. PMID: 35093206 doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(21)02004-3
